page.title: 19BIRDS IN KETTLEWELL
page.content: Apart from the usual common birds in the village, dippers, herons, and occasionally kingfishers, are found near the river. Goosanders and oyster-catchers breed regularly by the river. Grey and yellow wagtails are found, but sand martins have become scarce. Whilst there are no barn owls, tawny owls and a few little owls are seen. Short-eared owls occur on the high screes. In spring swifts and swallows, curlews, lapwings, nuthatches, and tree-creepers are seen. In winter field-fares gather and sometimes red-wings. The ring-ouzel is a summer visitor to high ground. Black-headed gulls and kestrels are common, and sparrow-hawks and rarer birds of prey can sometimes be seen. Red grouse, pheasants and some partridge are also found.
